Expectation1: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation1: The nursing assistant is on their morning rounds to take a patient's routine vital signs.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I glanced at my watch as I finished recording Mrs. Lee’s blood pressure. My shift as a nursing assistant was in full swing, and I still had three more patients to check before my break. Each minute mattered; the nurses depended on my timely reports to adjust medications. But today was also Election Day, and I’d promised myself I’d vote before my shift ended. I rushed to the polling station during my break, only to find a long line. As I finally neared the front, an official called out, “Voters with last names A–M, please move to the new line!” My last name started with “J.” The new line was much longer, but the official’s voice was firm. I hesitated, thinking of the patients waiting for their vitals, the nurses counting on me, and the rules I was supposed to follow as a voter. My heart pounded as I stood between the two lines, torn between my duty to my patients and my responsibility as a citizen.
